title: Identifying a Conic
text:
1) Rewrite the equation in the general form, $$A x^2+B x y+C y^2+D x+E y+F=0$$.
2) Identify the values of A and C from the general form.
a. If A and C are nonzero, have the same sign, and are not equal to each other, then the graph may be an ellipse.
$$b$$. If A and C are equal and nonzero and have the same sign, then the graph may be a circle.
c. If A and C are nonzero and have opposite signs, then the graph may be a hyperbola.
$$d$$. If either A or C is zero, then the graph may be a parabola.
If $$B=0$$, the conic section will have a vertical and/or horizontal axes. If B does not equal $$0$$, as shown below, the conic section is rotated. Notice the phrase “may be” in the definitions. That is because the equation may not represent a conic section at all, depending on the values of A, B, C, D, E, and F. For example, the degenerate case of a circle or an ellipse is a point:
$$A x^2+B y^2=0$$, when A and B have the same sign.
The degenerate case of a hyperbola is two intersecting straight lines: $$A x^2+B y^2=0$$, when A and B have opposite signs.
On the other hand, the equation, $$A x^2+B y^2+1=0$$, when A and B are positive does not represent a graph at all, since there are no real ordered pairs which satisfy it.

Notice the phrase “may be” in the definitions. That is because the equation may not represent a conic section at all, depending on the values of A, B, C, D, E, and F. For example, the degenerate case of a circle or an ellipse is a point:
   a x squared plus   b y squared is equal to 0 , when A and B have the same sign.
The degenerate case of a hyperbola is two intersecting straight lines:    a x squared plus   b y squared is equal to 0 , when A and B have opposite signs.
On the other hand, the equation,    a x squared plus   b y squared, plus 1 is equal to 0 , when A and B are positive does not represent a graph at all, since there are no real ordered pairs which satisfy it.

title: General Form
text: Referring to the general form $$A x^2+B x y+C y^2+D x+E y+F=0$$, we can identify the type of conic by comparing the coefficients.
speech: Referring to the general form    a x squared, plus   b x y, plus   c y squared, plus   d x plus   e y plus   f is equal to 0 , we can identify the type of conic by comparing the coefficients.

title: General Form
text: We notice that A and C have opposite signs. Based on the previous hint, what type of conic is this?
